comment_text:
Some notes on the intended use of this series. I was deliberate in using the phrase "tour of differential equations", as opposed to "introduction to" or "essence of". I think of the relationship between watching this series and taking a course as being analogous to the relationship between touring a city vs. living in it. You'll certainly see a lot less with the tour since you're spending less time overall, but the goal will be to walk around some of the most noteworthy monuments and town centers with helpful context given to you by a guide. And just as someone who lives in a city may very well have never gone to visit some of the historical sites of their town, despite living there for years, many differential equations students may not always get the chance to zoom out and appreciate the central cornerstones of the subject amidst all the computations they are learning.


I hope you enjoy the tour, but at the same time know that it is, by design, very different from taking courses on the subject.

As example of a ODE that indeed have a finite ending time at T=2:
x'=-sgn(x)*sqrt(|x|), x(0)=1
Could support the finite duration solution:
x(t)=1/4*(1-t/2+|1-t/2|)^2

7:39 I don't know/remember proper theorem names, but I'll give it a go.

Gravity is a vertical line going down, just like the measure of the angle theta, so they are parallel lines. So a line segment connecting them through them will have angles that total 180 degrees, just like in a parallelogram.* (You rotate one way, then rotate back around). The cyan vector a tangent line to the circle (due to physics), making a right angle, or 90 degrees from L. I'm also going to assume that the magenta vector is was constructed as a normal to the tangent, as that seems to be the intent, so it is also 90 degrees from the cyan vector.

Calling the angle t, the yellow vector Y, the cyan vector C, and the Magenta vector M, (and working in degrees for easy symbols) we now have the following:

Angle LY = 180 - t
Angle CY = LY - 90 = (180 - t) - 90 = 90 - t
Angle YM = 180 - (CY + CM) = 180 - ((90 - t) + 90)
= 180 - 90 + t - 90 = 180 - 180 + t = t

Thus the angle formed by the yellow and magenta vectors is in fact theta.

* I seem to remember there was some theorem that would make this easy. There were tons of theorems about lines crossing parallel lines. You could, for instance, extend L and see that the angle between that extension and the gravity (yellow) vector is theta, and then use another parallel line theorem (I think) to show that the desired vector is also theta.

But I can't remember them, and they weren't really necessary. I'm sure the math I did is basically just proving those theorems, anyways.

This series created only questions and didn't answer a single one. It contains as much understandable information as any popular science magazine. If you watch it, you think you understand everything. But just try to solve even one of these "simple" formulas yourself and it hits you through the ceiling. Because no one of them gets to the point.

After the series I tried to program a simple Fourier Transform algorithm. You bet what happened. I spent weeks on research, watched dozen of other not useful explanation video, read articles, asked questions in forums, and so on. Finally I found a tutorial on an unpopular German teacher's YouTube channel. And he answered the questions I had, and he got to the point. But after all that, watching these videos again, and asking me what I learned from them, the conclusion is: nothing!

This is just content to gain popularity and for self-actualization. "To be a name" and being considered good at math. But no one questions these contents. If you're like me and want to have fun with math, and do your own math, please just don't watch this videos. They will not help you! I don't recommend them.

I decided to look at this series again, since we're about to learn about differential equations in college.

From my limited knowledge, I learned to think of it in a comparison. When you have an equation, you have a value that you need to know, and for most cases there's only one number that solves the equation. In comparison, a function is a relationship between two unknowns, and there's no single answer for each one, but rather a set of all solutions for one when you set the other to a specific value, all of them represented in a graph. Then, on a different equation, you no longer have a single graph, but rather an infinite amount of graphs, each one depending on the starting conditions.

Maybe the analytical approach to solving differential equations we have is wrong. Maybe it's not a matter of finding θ(t), but rather being able to tell where the differential equation will take it for the following t. After all, who defines what the solution is but ourselves?

Intuitive proof for 7:30 :
extend the dotted line down.
scale up the triangle (preserving angles) so that cyan and magenta intersect on the dotted line.
the dotted and yellow lines both go directly downward and are therefore parallel.
cyan and magenta are defined to be perpendicular.
cyan is tangent to the circle whose radius is L, therefore cyan and L are perpendicular.
magenta and L are parallel.
the dotted and yellow lines both go directly downward and are therefore parallel.
the quadrilateral consisting of L, the dotted line, magenta and yellow is a parallelogram.
opposite angles (including the ones we set out to prove as equal) are equal in a parallelogram.
TL;DR: drop the dotted line, scale up the triangle boom parallelogram QED

Hi Grant, I studied the damped driven pendulum for my MSc investigation 1986-87. It is the simplest system showing all forms of chaos, because it has a 3-dimensional phase space, the phase of the sinusoidal driving force being the third dimension. It is topologically easy to see that a two dimensional phase space does not allow chaos, because the phase trajectory must escape intersecting itself and therefore can only spiral in, eventually, when it has a damping term. The damped driven pendulum has an exponentially contracting phase flow, but it settles on a strange attractor that has it moving in a never repeating but also never stopping bounded motion: a great definition of chaos. I had quite the epiphany when I realized at some point back then that this classical chaotic behavior forever breaks determinism, opening the door for free will...

On computers one might think that simulations of physical systems like pendula should calculate sines and cosines for each frame of animation, but that is too slow to model complex systems, since calculating a sine requires several arithmetic operations to provide sufficient precision.

There is an interesting mathematical area devoted to efficient yet accurate calculation of iterative approximate integrations. Basically, with sufficient precision it is possible to do an accurate integration step with one addition (after all, integration is just addition of very tiny function slices with the slice size approaching zero). The result is that high-speed animations of systems requiring many separate integrations of various orders are not difficult to program.

Some of my first professional software, in 1966, supported the rotation in displayed realtime 3D stereo pairs of experimental data plots on a simple computer (the LINC) with a very tiny memory that had no way to compute sines or cosines. I used high-precision addition and subtration, along with a table of 90 sine values to convert from degrees to a more natural internal angle representation.

If you’re wondering what the solution to the fox and rabbit equation is, there isn’t an explicit equation as a function of time.  However, it can be plotted implicitly with x=rabbits, y=foxes.  δx+βy-γln(x)-αln(y)=V, with V being constant for all t.  When you plot it as a function of time, you get periodic functions repeating every 2π/√(αγ) years (or whatever unit of time your using).  There also exist two equilibrium points where nothing ever changes: x=0, y=0 (extinction), or x=γ/δ, y=α/β.  The first is a saddle point, the second is an elliptic.  If you plot for x and y infinitesimally close to the second equilibrium, you’ll generate an x & y that circle around the equilibrium in an elliptical pattern.  Technically, you could represent the exact path taken by x & y in any situation by using a Fourier transform, but I couldn’t really be bothered to go that far 🤷‍♂️

Another important thing to learn from chaos theory is that there are times when we KNOW we can’t know something, and so we should not place our faith in those predictions. # Physical constants
g = 9.8
L = 2
mu = 0.1

THETA_0 = np.pi
THETA_DOT_0 = 0

#defining the OED
def get_theta_double_dot(theta, theta_dot):
return -mu * theta_dot - (g/L) * np.sin(theta)

#Solution to the differential equation
def theta(x):
theta = THETA_0
theta_dot = THETA_DOT_0
delta_t = 0.01
for time in np.arange(0, x, delta_t):
theta_double_dot = get_theta_double_dot(
theta, theta_dot
)
theta += theta_dot * delta_t
theta_dot += theta_double_dot * delta_t
return theta

Geometry Exercise: that angle is equal to theta by the fact that they are alternate interior angles. Extend the g vector to be one parallel line, extend the downward L radius to be another parallel line, extend original L to be a parallel line, and extend the small purple vector to be a second transversal. The angle between purple and g is equal to angle between line extended from purple vector to downward L by alternate interior angles. Take the vertical angle of this angle. By corresponding angles, that angle is equal to the angle formed by extended original L and downward L extended upward. This sounds confusing, but that angle is a vertical angle with the original theta, if that makes it a little more clear.

When I watched this video, I instantly began to compare my own relationship(s) with the Three Body Problem. I'm in a sort of love-triangle with two other guys, and our dynamics are.. complicated. Previously I lacked the language to describe the strange patterns by which our shared affections increase and decrease, but now I've gained a little insight. It's a little like three planets orbiting each other; the magnitude and direction of my feelings for one person are affected by the connection they have with the other person. There's this emotion that's kinda the polar opposite of jealousy; like a shared happiness, the pleasure you experience when you recognize something good existing between two other people. I always thought it was wacky that this feeling could coexist, or at least cycle somehow, with a completely opposite reaction; the neglect and exclusion that you get when you observe a seemingly stronger connection between two other people, than you personally have with either of them. But now I feel like I grasp the shape of this relationship; it's like a phase space, where the tendency of your reaction towards either supportiveness or jealousy is just another axis. At any give point in time, one of us generally has a radically different value with regard to this tendency, while the other two generally have more similar values. Rarely, however, we all match up. It seems correlated some compound variable, related to the amount of affection and time spent together, of each pairing out of the three of us. It's FASCINATING. Thank you so much for this video ~ I've been considering majoring in Psychology, but now I think I'm going to dual-major in psych and math. Who knows? Maybe I'll be able to come up with a really good mathematical model for romantic relationships.

I do most of my work in Python, and have actually been building a framework for composing algorithmic music in python. If anyone is trying to figure out the geometric exercise at 7:33, the idea is that the dotted line and the yellow line are parallel, which means the angle created by L is theta on the "right" side of both lines. Since the blue line and L make a right angle, that means the angle between blue and yellow is 90-theta. Since the angle between the blue and pink lines is 90 degrees, the third angle (between the pink and yellow) must be theta since 180=(90-theta)+(theta)+(90)

I basically solve all kinds of differential equations for living: modelling soft body dynamics, rigid body dynamics, optics, whatever. I just wanted to give an advice to anyone aspiring to learn all this stuff. What they often teach you at school/uni is how to solve these equations analytically : sure, this is sometimes useful. However, in most real applications, it's more productive to be able to write a program to solve them rather than to do that "manually". Even the simplest explicit solver that's literally 2 lines of code, instantly covers 95% of all differential equations, even though its performance and accuracy are not the best. It's kind of a brute force solution.


One might even start thinking that "hey, if my computer can just solve all these equations, why even bother studying them?". And the reason is very simple: by applying knowledge of certain types of DE's and by using more advanced solvers, one can increase performance and accuracy of these solvers by orders of magnitude. Which might make a huge difference: physics simulation in your game becomes more stable, your rendering algorithm can run your effects 60fps instead of 5fps, you can render your image in higher resolution on the same hardware, etc. My idea is, don't think of your computer as a replacement for your knowledge. Think of it as of an incredibly powerful tool, that still fully depends on your skill.

i recall forty yrs ago there was an ad in C&EN that described a novel way to "solve" an "insoluble" set of differential equations.  vaguely, as best as i can remember, it involved a mapping from the "insoluble" set of equations to a "soluble" set of equations.  does this make any sense to you, and if so, can you describe it please?

# phase space and spiral


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

g = 9.8
L = 2
tt = []
t_dot = []

#variables to initialize
mu = 0.9 # air resistance
THETA_0 = np.pi/3 # initial angle
THETA_DOT_0 = 8 # initial angular velocity

# Definition of ODE
def get_theta_double_dot(theta, theta_dot):
return -mu*theta_dot-(g/L)*np.sin(theta)

# Solution to the differential equation
def theta(t):
# Initialize changing values
theta = THETA_0
theta_dot = THETA_DOT_0
delta_t = 0.001 # some time step
for time in np.arange(0, t, delta_t):
theta_double_dot = get_theta_double_dot(theta, theta_dot)
theta += theta_dot * delta_t
tt.append(theta)
theta_dot += theta_double_dot * delta_t
t_dot.append(theta_dot)
#print(time,theta,theta_dot,theta_double_dot)
return theta

# spiral
theta(50)

# phase space X=theta, Y=U=theta_dot, V=theta_double_dot
span=np.pi
last_theta=abs(tt[-1])
scale=(last_theta//3)+1 #scaling xAxis on last value of theta
density=30
X, Y = np.meshgrid(np.linspace(-span, scale*span, density), np.linspace(-span,max(THETA_DOT_0,span), density))
U = Y
V = get_theta_double_dot(X,Y)

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
q = ax.quiver(X, Y, U, V, units='width')
ax.quiverkey(q, X=0.2, Y=1.05, U=0, label='Pendulum spiral in phase space', labelpos='E')
ax.plot(tt,t_dot)
#plt.title('Pendulum spiral in phase space')

plt.show()

Speaking about ODE. The first time I was completely mindblown away by it, is when you integrate complex number on the system.
Which is the idea of, the general solution of exponential function suddenly transformed into a trig/circular function because of imaginary unit.
It starts by finding that if the acceleration is positively proportional to it's position, then the position function of time have decay/increase rate of the square root of the proportion.
What if the proportion is negative? Do we need different solution? Because we can't take square root of negative number.

When you accept imaginary unit into the function, it's very bizarre at first that a physical phenomenon are allowed to have imaginary position. Where is the position in actual room if the position is imaginary?
It's crazy.
But when you complete all the parts (find all particular solutions), all those imaginary unit cancel out, and leaves out our familiar trig function. Thus we have, the simple harmonic motion solution. All real values.

That's when I fall in love with Physics.

These videos are a revolutionary step in the advancement of the teaching of math (and various other subjects).

It took me so long to be able to form the visual ideas in these videos during my math degrees. That's with an S. Because you have manuals with well written explanations, some good teachers that are able to help you get an understanding and all this got me to a point where I could sort of produce the animations in these videos in my head, if you will.

And having this level of understanding and being passionate about teaching, I have much experience in trying to help others understand certain topics. This can be compared to making the images in these videos appear in the student's mind.

For a math student, at this point in their career, they are mosly not too bothered with the learning of notations and the other tedium of math. The hard part is relating the notations to the true ideas.

An interesting thing: It took me years to understand deeply how all the math I was doing could be visualised this way. Because without videos like this, the only way you could communicate visual ideas about this subject was to take the person you are talking to, and teaching them advanced math, then using the language of advanced math to communicate the ideas.

Now, you can see the ideas, and THEN learn the math that is used to describe it. I think this makes these videos groundbreaking tools in the teaching of this subject.
Much appreciated.

There are other types of problems, which behave in a similar fashion. There is no general solution to some problems, or we do not fully understand them. But you can compute a very close approximation, which will be good enough for real world applications. This is where a mathematician would say: "It is impossible." And he or she is totally right. But a computer scientist would say: "Here is your solution." And he or she will also be right in terms of ε. I work as a hacker and I have to show weird solutions for quite normal problems. Wow that is a really elegant description of this topic.  I am involved in the design of hardware that is solving a system of second order differential equations using numerical methods based on a state space representation of the physical system.  What gets really interesting is based on designing high speed digital hardware that allows the state space model to be run in "real time" and synchronized to the physical system it is representing.  Synchronization of the state space to the physical system means the the state space model now acts as a Kalman filter and the synchronization through a classic control loop keeps the state space model always in convergence with the physical system.  Applying a small phase advance to the state space model then it becomes a very powerful and accurate predictor of the future state of the physical system - basically a control system "time travel machine"

I would just like to point out that:
- the first derivative of position is called velocity
- the second derivative of position is called acceleration
- the thirst derivative of position is called jerk
- the fourth derivative of position is called snap
- the fifth derivative of position is called crackle
- the sixth derivative of position is called pop
- if six derivatives of position aren't enough for you and you need a seventh, you're called a loon.

A really small point: You expressed the second derivative as ÿ, which is, fair enough, the most standard way to write it.

However, when I was first introduced to derivatives, my teacher wrote the dots above each other. I always found this to be more intuitive. After all, a derivative is notated as a dot above the function. And the second derivative is the derivative of the function (derivative of ...). Therefore I think it's more intuitive to follow that the second dot should be above this.

Again, it's a really small point, but I thought this might be something you might want to consider

Proof at 7:26 done:

If we extend the gravity vector into an infinite line, we know that, because it and the equilibrium position of the string (dotted line) are both vertical, they are parallel (Two lines with the same slope are parallel). Likewise, because the velocity in the direction of motion (blue) is tangent to the circle (given physics fact), it forms a right angle with the circle. Additionally, the blue and purple vectors form a right angle. Therefore, the new position of the string is parallel to the purple vector (Converse of Alternate Interior Angle Theorem). By the Alternate Interior Angle Theorem, if we extend the yellow vector indefinitely, the angle it makes with the string facing upwards is theta. Lastly, because the string and purple vector are parallel, the angle in question also measures theta (Corresponding Angles Postulate).
